Dedication clearly proved.

Grief transforms the ordinary—
Sunsets, songs, a child's laugh—
Into moments sharp with meaning,
Bittersweet on your behalf.

The body speaks what words cannot:
In sleepless nights and appetite lost,
In shoulders curved to bear the burden,
In tears that come at any cost.

How can you grieve? With truth and time,
With patience for your wounded self,
Honoring both pain and healing,
As they share your heart's deep shelf.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'How can you grieve and express loss?'

responses.text:
The Cartography of Absence

How can you grieve and express loss?
Perhaps through rituals of remembrance—
The lighting of candles on dark evenings,
Or planting trees that will outlive your pain.

Perhaps in art that bleeds across the page,
Colors and shapes giving form to formless ache,
Or music that resonates with the hollow spaces
Where someone once filled your days with sound.

Some speak their grief in community circles,
Voices trembling but supported by others
Who recognize the contours of this landscape,
Having walked similar valleys themselves.

Others write letters never to be sent,
Or whisper conversations to empty rooms,
Finding comfort in the familiar act
Of addressing the one who cannot answer.

Grief has no single language or expression,
No correct pathway through its wilderness.
It is as unique as the love that preceded it,
As individual as the relationship now changed.

How can you grieve and express loss?
However feels true to the bond that remains,
For in honoring your pain, you honor
The depth of connection that created it.

Uncharted Waters

How can you grieve and express loss?
When the dictionary holds no words
Vast enough to contain this ocean,
This sudden drowning in absence.

Perhaps through objects transformed—
A jacket unworn, now a relic,
A voicemail preserved like amber,
Fragments of presence in your hands.

Or in the body's own language:
Breath caught midway in the throat,
Knees meeting floor in surrender,
Hands pressed against chest in protest.

Some find voice in creation—
Paintbrushes dipped in sorrow,
Melodies that mirror the cadence
Of a heart learning to beat differently.

Others speak through quiet ritual,
Morning coffee at their favorite spot,
Birthdays marked with favorite flowers,
Keeping conversation with memory.

How can you grieve? By trusting
That each expression, however small,
Honors the magnitude of your love,
And the courage it takes to continue.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'How can you grieve and express loss?'

responses.text:
The Archaeology of Grief

How can you grieve and express loss?
By becoming an archaeologist of absence,
Carefully excavating layers of memory,
Brushing dust from artifacts of what was.

Sometimes grief speaks through the body—
A sudden collapse at the grocery store
When their favorite cereal appears on the shelf,
Or tears that ambush you at traffic lights.

Sometimes it manifests in strange collections:
Ticket stubs, birthday cards, an unwashed pillowcase
Holding the faintest molecule of their scent,
Treasures in a museum only you can curate.

Perhaps grief expresses itself in transformation—
The garden planted where they loved to sit,
The scholarship created in their name,
The stranger helped because they would have cared.

Or in conversations with the stars at night,
Words released like lanterns into darkness,
Questions without answers, love without recipient,
Yet somehow heard in the vast listening of space.

How can you grieve? By allowing each moment
Its own authentic shape and sound,
Knowing that loss rewrites your geography
Into a landscape only survivors can read.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Light breaks where no sun shines;'

responses.text:
Light breaks where no sun shines;
In shadows deep and corners blind,
Where darkness claims its ancient right
To shield the world from burning bright.

Yet still it comes, this inner glow,
Not from the sky, but depths below,
A flame that needs no cosmic fire
To lift the spirit ever higher.

In caverns deep beneath the earth,
In hearts where sorrow finds its birth,
The luminescence softly grows
A secret only silence knows.

For light exists beyond our sight,
In dreams that visit us at night,
In thoughts that spark behind closed eyes,
In love that never truly dies.

So seek not just the day's bright face,
But find that gentle, hidden grace
That breaks where darkness seems complete—
Where soul and timeless mystery meet.

Light breaks where no sun shines;
Through cracks in walls of ancient stone,
Through veils of doubt and shrouds of fear,
Illuminating worlds unknown.

Not all that glimmers needs the day,
Nor cosmic fire to cast its spell.
Some radiance comes from within,
From depths where quiet secrets dwell.

In chambers of the human heart,
Where grief has carved its hollow space,
A phosphorescence slowly blooms,
Defying darkness with its grace.

The mind contains its galaxies,

Where consciousness ignites itself,
A candle no wind has yet doused.

Remember this when night seems long,
And stars withdraw their silver light:
The truest dawn breaks from the soul,
Transforming blindness into sight.

For we are lanterns in ourselves,
Not merely mirrors of the sky.
The light that saves us comes from depths
Where even shadows learn to fly.

Light breaks where no sun shines;
In caverns deep and oceans cold,
Where creatures blind to daylight swim
And luminescence stories told.

A phosphorescence born of life,
Not borrowed from the distant star,
But generated from within—
A different kind of light, by far.

So too within the human soul,
Where darkness sometimes seems complete,
A spark can kindle without match,
Illuminating our defeat.

The light of insight, sudden, sharp,
Requires no external flame.
It bursts from neural wilderness,
No two ignitions quite the same.

Consider how in darkest times,
When hope seems but a memory,
Compassion glows like biolume,
A light that sets the spirit free.

Perhaps we need not chase the sun,
But learn to cultivate instead
The inner glow that never dims
And lights the path that waits ahead.

Light breaks where no sun shines;
In depths of ocean, cold and still,
Where creatures glow with inner fire
And darkness bends to living will.

Beneath the forest's tangled floor
Where roots communicate in code,
A fungal network pulses bright
With wisdom ancient and untold.

Within the caverns of the mind
Where thoughts like shadows dance and weave,
Insight flashes, sudden, clear—
A brilliance we can scarce believe.

In eyes of those who suffer long

A luminescence perseveres,
The stubborn lantern of the soul.

No solar rays can penetrate
The chambers where our grief resides,
Yet somehow healing light appears
From sources that the heart provides.

So seek not always skies above
For brightness that sustains your way.
The most enduring light of all
Breaks where no sun has thought to stray.

Light breaks where no sun shines;
In midnight's deepest, darkest hour,
When stars are hidden, moon is gone,
And shadow holds its greatest power.

Not all illumination comes
From cosmic bodies burning bright.
Some radiance defies all laws—
A contradiction to the night.

Deep in the earth where crystals grow,
No ray has ever penetrated,
Yet minerals emit a glow
That science has not calculated.

Within the mind's labyrinthine halls
Where memories both die and form,
A consciousness creates its spark
That no external force can warm.

Perhaps the truest light of all
Is that which needs no outside source,
But generates from mystery,
From life's uncharted, primal force.

So when you stand in darkness deep
And feel that all bright things have fled,
Remember how light always breaks
In places where no sun has spread.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'They were indeed simple people'

responses.text:
Simple Folk

They were indeed simple people,
With hands weathered by honest toil,
Their wisdom not from books but seasons,
Bound to the rhythm of the soil.

No grand ambitions cluttered their minds,
No hunger for fortune or fame,
Just the quiet joy of a meal shared,
And hearth-fires that whispered their name.

In their simplicity lay a wealth
That kings with crowns could never know—
The richness of untroubled slumber,
And hearts that had the space to grow.

They marked their days by sun and moon,
Not by the ticking of a clock,
Found meaning in the changing leaves,
And strength within the weathered rock.

They were indeed simple people,
And in that simplicity, profound.
Their legacy not carved in marble,
But in the love that they unbound.

Ordinary Miracles

They were indeed simple people,
Unadorned with wealth or scholarly claim,
Who rose with roosters, slept with darkness,
And rarely traveled beyond their name.

Their hands told stories words could not—
Calloused palms and dirt-lined nails,
Wrinkled roadmaps of a life lived close
To earth and sky and shifting gales.

Their kitchen table, scarred and worn,
Held more truth than marble halls.
Their laughter, unrefined but real,
Echoed warmly off humble walls.

No algorithms guided their choices,
No screens reflected in their eyes,
Just instinct born of generations
And wisdom passed without disguise.

They were indeed simple people—
Yet in their simplicity lay art:
The profound grace of being human,
And the courage of an open heart.

The Forgotten Sages

They were indeed simple people,
Whose names history failed to keep.
Their monuments were not of marble,
But furrows in the fields they'd reap.

No complicated theories spun,
No philosophies to debate.
Their truth was in the rising sun,
And in the garden's humble fate.

The world called them unremarkable,
Overlooked their quiet grace,
Never seeing how their gentle hands
Held galaxies in their embrace.

They spoke in proverbs, worn but true,
Passed down through generations long.
Their wisdom wasn't learned in schools,
But in the chorus of life's song.

They were indeed simple people,
Yet in simplicity profound.
For in their unassuming hearts,
The secrets of the world were found.

Beneath Notice

They were indeed simple people,
Beneath the notice of the proud,
Whose hands were rough with honest labor,
Whose voices rarely grew too loud.

No histories record their passing,
No monuments bear their plain names.
They lived and died in quiet corners,
Untouched by fortune or by fame.

Yet in their simple ways lay wisdom
That scholars seldom comprehend—
The patient rhythm of the seasons,
The faithful presence of a friend.

They knew the language of the rainfall,
Could read the warnings in the sky,
Found joy in homemade bread still steaming,
And peace as twilight hours passed by.

They were indeed simple people,
But in their simplicity divine—
For greatness isn't measured always
By what is complex or refined.

Heritage

They were indeed simple people,
Who asked for little, gave much more,
Whose wealth was measured not in silver
But in the kindness that they bore.

They built their lives on steady rhythms—
The planting time, the harvest moon,
The Sunday gatherings for worship,
The children's laughter, gone too soon.

No grand ambitions stirred their dreaming,
No hunger for a brighter stage.
Content to tend their modest garden,
And face each struggle, age by age.

Their hands told stories of persistence,
Their eyes reflected storms endured.
Their silence spoke of deep acceptance
Of truths that cannot be obscured.

They were indeed simple people—
My grandparents, my flesh and bone.
And in their simple ways, I find myself,
A legacy I'm proud to own.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Shake out my pockets! Harken to the call'

responses.text:
EMPTY POCKETS

Shake out my pockets! Harken to the call
Of coins that tumble, keys that softly ring.
The lint of days, receipts of choices small,
These treasures humble that my fingers bring.

Within these folds of fabric, stories hide,
A ticket stub from journeys long complete,
A pebble smooth that turned with ocean tide,
A note folded with words no longer sweet.

Shake out my pockets! Let the contents fall
Like memories cascading to the floor.
The weight I've carried, both the large and small,
Now scattered wide through time's relentless door.

For in this emptying, I find release,
These trinkets shed, my spirit finds its peace.

THE SUMMONING

Shake out my pockets! Harken to the call
Of ancient spirits dancing in the wind.
The universe awaits beyond the wall
Where mortal coils and cosmic threads have thinned.

I empty out the burdens that I bear—
Coins of regret and keys to doors long closed,
The talismans I've gathered everywhere,
The secrets that I've carefully enclosed.

The calling grows more urgent with each breath,
A whispered summons from the void beyond.
It speaks of life transcending fear and death,
Of breaking every hesitating bond.

So shake these pockets clean of earthly things!
The journey calls—hear how the darkness sings!

SURRENDER

Shake out my pockets! Harken to the call
Of liberation's sweet, insistent voice.
The weight of gathering, the need to haul
These trinkets home—no longer is my choice.

What fills these spaces? Fragments of my days:
A subway token, crumpled shopping list,
A smooth stone gathered where the river plays,
A photograph of someone barely missed.

The world demands we carry as we go,
Collecting proof of where our feet have trod.
But lighter steps might help us better know
The path ahead, the whispers of our God.

So empty now these cloth repositories,
And free yourself from all these inventories.

POCKETS OF TIME

Shake out my pockets! Harken to the call
Of moments trapped in fabric's hidden fold.
The hours spent beneath the waterfall,
The minutes warmed by stories that you told.

These pockets hold more treasures than appear—
A universe of seconds, neatly tucked
Beside the coins and keys we hold so dear,
And memories that time has nearly plucked.

I turn them inside out and watch it fall:
Confetti made of laughter, tears, and sighs.
The calendar of days both great and small,
The measured beats of countless lullabies.

Our pockets, like our hearts, contain it all—
The remnants of a life lived full and tall.

THE VAGABOND'S PRAYER

Shake out my pockets! Harken to the call
Of freedom's wild and untamed melody.
I've wandered far beyond the city's wall,
A drifter bound by nothing save the sea.

My pockets hold no gold or precious stone,
Just tickets from the trains that I have caught,
A compass pointing to the great unknown,
A pen with which my journeys I have wrought.

The richest man counts wealth in gleaming piles,
But I count mine in roads that I have walked,
In foreign tongues and unforgotten smiles,
In strangers' tales where wisdom softly talked.

So shake these pockets empty to the sky!
For lighter travels he who learns to fly.

responses.text:
Light breaks where no sun shines;
Through the obsidian vault of night,
A luminescence beyond sight
Defies the cosmos and its designs.

Not born of fusion's distant roar,
Nor borrowed from celestial spheres,
This radiance transcends all fears
And pierces what we once ignored.

In quantum realms where laws dissolve,
In consciousness's hidden folds,
In myths that ancient stars foretold,
The paradox we can't resolve.

Perhaps the darkness is a veil,
A canvas for the truest light—
Not blinding in its naked might
But subtle as a whispered tale.

The universe inverts itself
When we abandon what we know;
The deepest wisdom seems to flow
From voids where reason finds no help.

So honor now this strange decree:
That brilliance needs no source at all,
That in the great primeval fall,
Light breaks—and sets perception free.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Shake out my pockets! Harken to the call'

responses.text:
EMPTY POCKETS

Shake out my pockets! Harken to the call
Of lint and coins that scatter to the floor.
The artifacts of daily life, so small,
Yet each a story, each a metaphor.

A ticket stub from journeys long ago,
A folded note with fading words of love,
A pebble smooth, collected just to show
The beauty found below, not just above.

Shake out my pockets! Let the contents spill,
The treasures and the trash of passing days.
The keys to doors I've entered at my will,
The receipts for moments spent in countless ways.

For in these pockets lie the proof I've lived,
Not measured by the wealth that I have gained,
But by the trinkets thoughtlessly received,
And purposefully, lovingly retained.

THE SUMMONING

Shake out my pockets! Harken to the call
Of ancient spirits dancing in the wind.
The universe has beckoned, standing tall,
To empty what was hoarded, what was pinned.

The copper coins of childhood, worn and thin,
The folded dreams I never dared pursue,
The memories of places I have been,
All tumble forth in morning's gentle dew.

Shake out my pockets! Free what's hidden there!
The burdens carried silently too long,
The weight of expectations hard to bear,
The fragments of an unfinished song.

For only empty can we truly fill
With purpose new and visions yet unseen.
To answer life's great summons with goodwill,
We must first clear what lies in space between.

SURRENDER

Shake out my pockets! Harken to the call
Of liberation's sweet, insistent voice.
Watch as my worldly treasures rise and fall,
A rain of trinkets, not by chance, but choice.

The currency of kingdoms cannot buy
What waits beyond attachment's heavy chain.
These metal discs that glimmer, catch the eye,
Are anchors to a shore of needless pain.

Shake out my pockets! See how light I am
When unburdened by possessions' fickle charm.
The emptiness becomes a telegram
From freedom's realm where nothing brings us harm.

I stand before you, penniless but whole,
My richness measured not in what I own,
But in the vast expanses of my soul,
Now spacious as the sky, and just as known.

THE VAGABOND'S CREED

Shake out my pockets! Harken to the call
Of highways stretching endless 'neath the stars.
The wanderer's possessions, few and small,
Tell stories of the distances and scars.

A matchbook from a tavern miles behind,
A foreign coin from hands I'll never touch,
A tattered map with corners worn and lined,
A bottlecap - to some not worth as much.

Shake out my pockets! Witness now my wealth:
The freedom of the unencumbered road.
No mansion grand, no promise of good health,
Just footsteps forward, lightening my load.

For I have traded safety for the thrill
Of never knowing where I'll rest my head.
The pocket's call - adventure's sacred will -
Demands I follow where the path has led.

REVELATION

Shake out my pockets! Harken to the call
That echoes from the chambers of the heart.
The jangling keys and coins begin to fall,
As hidden treasures make their trembling start.

What lies within these fabric depths so deep?
The ticket stubs of journeys never made,
The promises I struggled hard to keep,
The photographs of memories that fade.

Shake out my pockets! Watch as truth appears
In humble objects carried day by day.
The evidence of laughter, love, and tears,
The proof of paths both taken and astray.

For in this simple act of emptying,
I find myself more honestly revealed
Than in the careful words I'm trumpeting—
My truest self, no longer kept concealed.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Shake out my pockets! Harken to the call'

responses.text:
EMPTY VESSELS

Shake out my pockets! Harken to the call
Of emptiness that beckons to be filled.
The hollow spaces where we store it all—
Our secrets, hopes, and dreams we have distilled.

Turn inside out these fabric caves of mine,
Let fall what clings to linings worn and thin.
The crumpled notes, the coins that no more shine,
The dust of journeys where my feet have been.

Shake out my pockets! Let the world behold
What I have gathered on this winding way.
Not treasures made of silver or of gold,
But fragments of each vivid yesterday.

For we are but the carriers of time,
Collectors of the moments as they pass.
Our pockets brimming with the sweet sublime,
Until we pour them empty on the grass.

THE RECKONING

Shake out my pockets! Harken to the call
Of conscience crying from the depths within.
The time has come to reckon with it all—
The virtues I have lost, the weight of sin.

What trinkets have I hoarded in these folds?
What evidence of greed or kindness shown?
What stories do these gathered items hold
Of who I truly am, what I have grown?

Shake out my pockets! Let the judgment start,
As each collected object tells its tale.
The honest mirror held up to my heart
Reveals if I have thrived or if I've failed.

For in the end, we carry what we are—
The choices made, the paths we did not take.
The pockets of our lives, near and far,
Hold truths we cannot hide, cannot forsake.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Shake out my pockets! Harken to the call'

responses.text:
THE COSMIC JANGLE

Shake out my pockets! Harken to the call
Of universes tucked in cotton folds.

The coins are planets, spinning as they fall,

A subway token marks where worlds collide,

Shake out my pockets! Stars cascade like sand,

responses.text:

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Shake out my pockets! Harken to the call'

Pockets' Proclamation

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'They were indeed simple people'

responses.text:
Simple Souls

They were indeed simple people,
With calloused hands and weathered skin,
Their wealth not counted in silver or gold
But in the harvest they'd gather in.

No grand philosophies guided their way,
Just the rhythm of seasons, the pull of the land.
They rose with the sun and rested at dusk,
Their lives like water poured into sand.

They spoke few words but meant them all,
Their promises solid as ancient oak.
They laughed without pretense, cried without shame,
And carried each other when spirits broke.

They were indeed simple people,
Uncomplicated in wants and needs,
Yet in their simplicity lay wisdom profound—
A life well-lived through honest deeds.

The Unadorned

They were indeed simple people,
Neither burdened by ambition's weight
Nor enchanted by fortune's fickle smile.
Their homes stood modest against the hills,
Windows catching morning light
Like cupped hands holding water.

Their conversations flowed like gentle streams,
Untroubled by intellectual pretense
Or the desperate need to impress.
They marked time not by ticking clocks
But by the height of corn,
The migration of birds,
The first frost painting the fields.

In their simplicity lay a certain grace—
A knowledge that contentment
Need not be purchased or pursued.
It lived in shared bread,
In stories passed down like heirlooms,
In the quiet dignity of work completed well.

They were indeed simple people,
And in their unadorned existence,
They mastered what the wise spend lifetimes seeking.

Ordinary Miracles

They were indeed simple people,
Whose names history would never record.
No monuments would bear their faces,
No textbooks tell their tales.

They lived in humble dwellings
Where love was served at wooden tables,
Where laughter echoed off plain walls
And sorrows were shouldered together.

They mended what was broken,
Replanted after every storm,
And found beauty in the ordinary—
A child's first steps, a sunset's glow,
The perfect ripeness of summer fruit.

They were indeed simple people,
Who measured wealth in moments shared,
In kindnesses exchanged like currency,
In traditions preserved like precious gems.

Perhaps simplicity itself
Was their greatest achievement—
This knowing that greatness
Need not announce itself with trumpets,
But whispers in the quiet acts
Of hearts that understand enough.

The Unsung

They were indeed simple people,
Untroubled by fame's seductive call.
Their legacy: not marble monuments
But trees they'd planted, standing tall.

No complex theories shaped their thoughts,
No grand ambitions drove their days.
They found their purpose close to earth,
In honest work and humble ways.

Their wisdom wasn't born of books
But carved from life's relentless tide—
The patient strength to weather storms,
The grace to take each day in stride.

Their hands built homes and tended fields,
Their hearts held space for joy and grief.
They measured time by seasons' turns,
And found in simple things relief.

Perhaps in this accelerated age,
Where complexity commands the stage,
We've lost the art they mastered well:
To live completely, clear and true,
Without the need for grand debut—
A story beautiful to tell.

Beneath Notice

They were indeed simple people,
Overlooked by history's selective gaze,
Dismissed by those who measure worth
In acquisition and acclaim.

Yet in their unassuming hands,
The world was quietly maintained—
Fields tended, children raised,
Communities sustained.

They carried ancient knowledge
Not in books but bone and blood:
How to read the changing sky,
How to make the bitter sweet,
How to find the sacred in the mundane.

No complexity of language
Could improve their silent truths—
That love outlasts ambition,
That kindness matters more than cunning,
That beauty dwells in broken things.

They were indeed simple people,
And perhaps therein lay their gift:
To live unburdened by pretense,
To die having truly known themselves,
To leave behind a legacy
Of moments genuinely lived.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Shake out my pockets! Harken to the call'

responses.text:
Shake Out My Pockets

Shake out my pockets! Harken to the call
Of trinkets tumbling, memories released—
A ticket stub, a smooth stone from the beach,
A folded note whose words I still recall.

These treasures carried close against my chest,
Burdening my journey, weighing me down.
Now scatter them like seeds across the ground,
And watch what blooms when I am dispossessed.

The coins that jingle speak of wealth amassed,
The lint collected speaks of time gone by,
The keys to doors I've locked against the past.

Shake out my pockets! Let the wind decide
What merits keeping, what deserves to fly.
I'll walk unburdened under open sky,
With empty pockets and a lighter stride,
Responding only to the freedom's call.

The Summoning

Shake out my pockets! Harken to the call
Of copper pennies dancing on the floor,
Of crumpled receipts and forgotten lore,
Of dust and dreams that cling to wall and wall.

The universe resides in these small things—
A button from my father's favorite coat,
A pebble from the stream where we would float
Paper boats beneath the bridge in springs.

Harken! The whispers of what once was mine,
Now scattered like confetti to the air.
Each object holds a story, worn and bare,
Testaments to journeys along time's line.

Empty now, my pockets breathe anew,
Ready to collect tomorrow's treasures,
Life's ephemera, its simple pleasures,
As I walk forward into morning dew.

Shake out your pockets! Listen to their song—
The melody of living, brief but strong.

Pockets of Existence

Shake out my pockets! Harken to the call
Of forgotten artifacts and scattered dreams,
The detritus of days, the proof of schemes,
The evidence that I have lived at all.

Here lies a subway token, smooth and worn,
A paper clip bent into strange design,
A fortune from a cookie, words divine,
A thread from where my favorite shirt was torn.

What stories do these humble objects tell?
What journeys have they taken, pressed to thigh,
What conversations heard while nestled there?

They've felt my body's warmth, my motion's swell,
Been carried under both the moon and sky,
Companions to my wandering everywhere.

Shake out my pockets! Let the contents fall
Like autumn leaves, like memories, like rain—
Then gather what you will, begin again,
The pockets of existence hold us all.

The Emptying

Shake out my pockets! Harken to the call
Of liberation from the things we hold—
The burdens carried, stories left untold,
The weight of worlds both great and very small.

See how they tumble—coins and keys and lint,
The scraps of paper bearing scribbled notes,
A pebble from the shore, a ticket stub,
Fragments of a life lived on the fly.

What riches hide within these cloth confines?
What secrets do we carry next to skin?
The evidence of where our feet have trod,
The proof of purchases and paths we've made.

Harken now! The sound of emptiness,
The lightness that comes after letting go.
My pockets flattened, nothing left to show
Except the space where something used to be.

And in that void, a new world can begin,
Unburdened by the trinkets of the past.
Shake out your pockets—feel yourself at last,
And answer to the freedom's distant din.

Pocket Universe

Shake out my pockets! Harken to the call
Of chaos and creation intertwined.
What galaxies of lint and lost designs
Have gathered in these fabric depths to fall?

A brass key to a door I can't recall,
A ticket for a journey left behind,
A smooth stone picked up when the sun still shined,
A folded note pressed flat against the wall.

Each object tells a story, holds a world—
A universe contained in cotton folds.
The archaeology of everyday,

The sediment of living, slowly curled
Into these spaces where the darkness holds
The evidence of how we make our way.

Shake out my pockets! Watch as planets spin
And constellations form upon the floor.
The cosmos of my wanderings, and more—
The map of everywhere that I have been.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Shake out my pockets! Harken to the call'

Empty Pockets, Full Heart

The Vagabond's Anthem

My wealth is in the sunrise and the stars,

Shake out my pockets! See, there's nothing there

I am the child of highways and of rain,
Of mountain paths and meadows wild with bloom.
My heart beats time to distant thunder's drum,

So shake them out! And hear the call once more:
The world awaits beyond the open door.

Forgotten Treasures

Shake out my pockets! Harken to the call
Of trinkets tumbling to the waiting floor.

A subway token from a rainy night,

Adventures yet to come, a button bright,

What wealth we carry, unbeknownst to all!
The universe contained in spaces small.
The lint of yesterday, the coins of chance,
The keys to doors we've closed, or never found.

Our pockets hold the fragments of our lives,
The breadcrumb trail of where our hearts have been.
The evidence of journeys, loves and loss,
Of battles fought, surrendered, or to win.

So empty them! Let all your treasures fall!
Embrace the lightness, answer to the call.
For in releasing what we thought was ours,
We find ourselves, at last, completely free.

The Beggar's Wisdom

Shake out my pockets! Harken to the call
Of emptiness, the hollowest of sounds.
No silver coins to jingle as they fall,
No golden treasures waiting to be found.

Yet in this void, a freedom takes its form,
A weightlessness that wealthy men would crave.
Unburdened by possessions' endless storm,
I walk this earth unfettered as a wave.

The rich man counts his coins with furrowed brow,
And fears the thief who lurks behind each tree.
While I, with nothing worldly to endow,
Have nothing worldly that can be taken from me.

My wealth is in the sunset's crimson glow,
The birdsong that accompanies the dawn,
The whisper of the wind, the river's flow,
The dew that sparkles on the morning lawn.

So shake them out! My pockets, bare and worn!
From emptiness, true wisdom can be born.

The Summoning

Shake out my pockets! Harken to the call
Of ancient things that slumber in the deep.
The coins of realms long crumbled into dust,
The keys to doors where shadows never sleep.

Within these folds of fabric, time congeals,
A universe of mysteries untold.
The ticket to dimensions unexplored,
The map to treasures more precious than gold.

What magic lurks within these simple seams?
What spells are woven in this common cloth?
The lint of stars, the dust of distant dreams,
The remnants of what time has long since lost.

So turn them inside out! Release the spell!
Let fall what hides between the worlds we know.
For in the space between what is and was,
The seeds of transformation start to grow.

So empty now, yet somehow fuller still—

Pockets of Wonder

Shake out my pockets! Harken to the call
Of trinkets, treasures, tokens of the past.
Small artifacts of moments, big and small,
Collected memories, not meant to last.

A subway ticket from that rainy day,
A polished stone from shores of distant lands,
A folded note with words you meant to say,
A coin that warmed between our holding hands.

Shake out my pockets! Watch as they reveal
The story of a life in fragments told.
The mundane items somehow seem to steal
Importance far beyond their weight in gold.

For what are pockets but the quiet space
Where daily life accumulates its trace?
Where bits of living find their resting place,
And ordinary things gain special grace.

So when you call to empty what I keep,
Remember that these scraps define my way—
The breadcrumb trail of paths both wide and steep
That maps the journey I have walked today.

The Pocket Universe

Shake out my pockets! Harken to the call
Of emptiness that yearns to be fulfilled.
The void that waits, patient through it all,
For treasures and for trinkets to be spilled.

What mysteries these fabric caves contain—
A universe of objects, large and small.
From subway tokens wet with summer rain
To folded notes pressed flat against the wall.

The seeds I gathered from the maple tree,

These artifacts of ordinary days
Speak volumes of the life that I have led.
Each object tells a story, each conveys
A memory that dances in my head.

So shake them out and listen to their song,
The symphony of items taking flight.
For in these simple things where they belong,
Lies evidence that I have lived just right.

The Surrender

Shake out my pockets! Harken to the call
Of liberation from the things we hold.
The burdens carried, both the great and small,
Now tumbling free like nuggets rough with gold.

What have I kept so close against my thigh?
A matchbook from a restaurant we loved,
A smooth stone from beneath an autumn sky,
A feather that a sparrow once had shoved.

The crumpled bills, the coins of little worth,
The scraps of paper with forgotten notes,
The evidence of wandering this earth,
The talismans on which my spirit floats.

In emptying these caverns of my clothes,
I find myself unburdened, strangely light.
The weight of what I carried, no one knows,
Until it's spread before them, brought to light.

So shake them out! Let gravity command
The fall of all that I've collected here.
The universe contained within my hand
Now scattered wide for everyone to peer.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We sink into the dust,'

responses.text:
We sink into the dust,
Like stars that fade at dawn,
Our footprints soon erased
By time's relentless yawn.

We sink into the dust,
Returning what was lent,
The atoms of our being
To earth's dark firmament.

We sink into the dust,
Yet from our ending springs
The promise of renewal,
The hope that nature brings.

We sink into the dust,
But memories remain,
Etched in the hearts of those
Who knew our joy and pain.

We sink into the dust,
A humble truth, yet grand—
That in our brief existence
We touched this ancient land.

We sink into the dust,
As all things must return
To that from which they came—
The soil, the ash, the urn.

The grandest human schemes,
The mountains we have moved,
The empires we have built,
The theories we have proved—

All crumble into sand,
All whisper into air,
All fold into the earth
That neither knows nor cares.

Yet in this fading light,
This slow dissolving form,
I find a strange delight,
A peace amid the storm.

For we are but the dust
That briefly learned to dance,
That briefly learned to love,
That briefly got the chance

To witness stars and seas,
To taste the morning dew—
We sink into the dust,
But oh, what dust we knew.

We sink into the dust,
As daylight fades to dusk.
The world that we have known
Dissolves to seed and bone.

We sink into the dust,
Surrendering our trust
To earth's eternal hold,
Where stories end untold.

The hands that built great walls,
The voices raised in halls,
The minds that dreamed of flight,
All vanish in the night.

Yet in this quiet fall,
This ending shared by all,
There lies a sacred truth:
We bloom again as proof

That nothing truly dies,
But merely multiplies
In different forms and ways,
Through endless nights and days.

So as we sink from view,
Our essence born anew,
Remember we're not lost—
Just changed at gentle cost.

We sink into the dust,
Our bodies slowly fade,
Returning to the earth
From which we all were made.

The cosmic dance continues,
As atoms rearrange,
What once was flesh and blood
Now undergoes a change.

The mountains and the seas,
The stars that dot the sky,
All share this common fate—
To live and then to die.

But death is not an end,
Merely transformation,
A shifting of the form,
A quiet celebration

Of matter's endless cycle,
Of energy preserved.
Though consciousness may vanish,
Our essence is conserved.

So fear not this descent,
This sinking into ground.
In dust, we're not defeated—
In dust, we are unbound.

We sink into the dust,
Like autumn leaves that fall,
Surrendering ourselves
To time's relentless call.

The empires we build,
The fortunes we amass,
All tumble into silence,
As fleeting moments pass.

Yet in this slow descent,
This gentle fading light,
I find a strange communion
With those who've left our sight.

For dust connects us all—
The ancient and the new,
The pharaohs and the peasants,
The many and the few.

Perhaps in dust we find
The truth we seek to know:
That greatness lies in kindness,
In seeds of love we sow.

So as we sink from view,
Remember this we must:
Our legacy's not measured
By what escapes the dust.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We sink into the dust,'

responses.text:
Dust to Dust

We sink into the dust,
grains of time slipping through fingers,
each moment a particle returning
to the earth that birthed us.

We sink into the dust,
our footprints fading on well-worn paths,
where ancestors tread before,
where children will follow after.

We sink into the dust,
humbled by the vastness of stars,
by the smallness of our lives,
temporary as morning dew.

We sink into the dust,
not in defeat but in belonging,
returning to the primal source,
the ancient cycle unbroken.

We sink into the dust,
and in this dissolution find freedom,
as our atoms rejoin the cosmic dance,
endless, beautiful, complete.

Dissolution

We sink into the dust,
our bodies yielding to gravity's pull,
to time's relentless march.
The weight of existence presses down,
collapsing the architecture of bone and dream.

We sink into the dust,
our memories dissolving like salt,
the taste of life lingering briefly
before dispersing into the soil.
What remains of love? Of struggle?

We sink into the dust,
joining countless others who fell before,
their names erased from stone,
their stories scattered like seeds.
Yet from this dissolution, wildflowers emerge.

We sink into the dust,
not as endings but transformations,
our elements reconfigured, repurposed,
breathing again through blade of grass,
through wing of moth, through child's laughter.

We sink into the dust,
and the dust rises as us.

Earthbound

We sink into the dust,
As stars once did to form this ground,
A cosmic circle closing in
On lives that flared then dimmed again.

We sink into the dust,
Our pride and power rendered meek,
The kings and beggars side by side,
All equal in earth's hungry beak.

We sink into the dust,
Yet something of us still remains—
The echo of a kindness shown,
A love that breaks through mortal chains.

We sink into the dust,
But first we dance upon its face,
Leaving footprints, building dreams,
Creating beauty, sharing grace.

We sink into the dust,
And in this truth find strange relief,
That we are part of something vast,
Our briefest joy, our deepest grief.

We sink into the dust,
And from our ending, life renews.
In this surrender, find the seed
Of all that falls and all that blooms.

Return

We sink into the dust,
silent as snowfall on December fields,
our bodies surrendering what was never truly ours—
breath borrowed from ancient winds,
blood warmed by a distant star.

We sink into the dust,
joining the communion of bone and root,
our stories seeping into soil,
whispered through mycelia networks,
translated into the language of oak and pine.

We sink into the dust,
and the dust remembers us,
not as we imagined ourselves to be—
important, separate, eternal—
but as we truly were: momentary arrangements
of stardust and water, consciousness and light.

We sink into the dust,
and in this dissolution find our truth.
Not an ending but a returning,
not a failure but fulfillment,
the final verse of a poem
that begins again with every birth.

Ephemeral

We sink into the dust,
Our monuments and markers fade,
Time's gentle erosion claims us all,
No matter what we've made or said.

We sink into the dust,
Like autumn leaves on forest floor,
Our brilliance briefly celebrated,
Then part of earth forevermore.

We sink into the dust,
Yet in this fading find our worth,
For what is precious if not fleeting?
What is sacred but return to earth?

We sink into the dust,
And join the chorus of the gone,
Our elements recycled endlessly,
In death and life, we carry on.

We sink into the dust,
But first we breathe, we love, we burn—
A momentary constellation,
A pattern never to return.

We sink into the dust,
And in this knowledge lies our task:
To shine with fierce intensity
For this one moment that we have.

Beyond the Cinders

So search beyond the fables and the fairy tales,

I'll break into your thoughts—

Cognitive Invasion

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Please spare me your secrets'

responses.text:
Please Spare Me Your Secrets

Please spare me your secrets,
Those whispers in the night,
The shadows of your conscience,
That flee from morning light.

I have my own dark corners,
Where untold stories dwell,
A graveyard of confessions,
Too numerous to tell.

Your truths become my burden,
Once spoken, can't be shed,
They echo in my silence,
And haunt me in my bed.

Some knowledge is a poison,
That slowly kills the soul,
Some words cannot be unheard,
Some breaks cannot be whole.

So keep your hidden chapters,
The pages torn and creased,
Let me remain untroubled,
My conscience still at peace.

The Keeper of Secrets

Please spare me your secrets,
I'm weary of their weight.
The burden of your hidden truths
Is more than I can take.

Each whispered revelation
Is a stone upon my chest,
A confidence that binds me
To your unspoken mess.

I've become a vault of shadows,
A guardian of shame,
Holding what you dare not own,
Yet I am not to blame.

Your secrets crawl like spiders
Across my restless dreams.
They poison quiet moments
With their silent, urgent screams.

So please, I beg, keep counsel
With your own reflecting glass.
I cannot be the vessel
Where your darkness comes to pass.

Walls of Glass

Please spare me your secrets,
I've built my walls too thin,
Transparent as the morning dew,
Revealing all within.

Your whispered confidences
Seep through like bitter rain,
Staining all my quiet thoughts
With residue of pain.

I cannot be the keeper
Of truths you fear to face,
Nor can I bear the weight of words
That time cannot erase.

My heart's a fragile vessel,
Not meant for toxic brew,
Of mysteries and hidden sins
Best known to only you.

So keep your shadowed stories,
Your guilt, regret, and fear.
I need the light of simple truth,
The air around me clear.

Unspoken

Please spare me your secrets,
Those fragments of your past,
The sins you've tucked in corners,
The shadows that you cast.

I am not your confessor,
Nor absolution's key,
The weight of what you hide away
Was never meant for me.

Each confidence's a contract,
A chain I cannot break,
A knowledge that transforms me
In ways I didn't stake.

Some truths are best left buried,
Some words should not take flight,
Some burdens weren't designed to share
No matter how they might.

So keep your chest of mysteries,
Lock tight what lies within.
I'd rather know the person now
Than ghosts of where you've been.

The Unwilling Confidant

Please spare me your secrets,

The darkness you've been hiding
The seeds you chose to sow.

Each confidence you offer
Is not a gift but debt,
A burden shared becomes a bond
Too strong to soon forget.

I've carried others' stories
Until my back was bent,
A silent, loyal keeper
Of words I can't unspent.

The truth can be a weapon,
A double-edged, sharp knife,
That cuts the one who speaks it

Beyond the Slipper

So when we speak of Cinderella,

A light that shines through any weather,

The Essence of Cinderella

Cinderella means the personality or beauty of a person,
Not the soot-stained girl who scrubs the floor,

She is the patience in your waiting,

The graceful heart still celebrating
When bridges all around have burned.

She dwells not in the castle's grandeur,

But in the strength that doesn't surrender
Through lonely nights and thankless days.

Cinderella lives in every woman
Who rises from the ashes of despair,
Who finds her worth beyond the human
Judgments that would leave her bare.

So look beyond the midnight dances,
The glass that fits a dainty toe,
And see instead the soul that chances
To be herself—and thereby grow.

Cinderella Reimagined

Cinderella means the personality or beauty of a person,
A truth far deeper than fairy tales convey.
Not measured by the fitting of a slipper,
But by the light that guides her way.

She is not made by fairy godmother's magic,

Her worth was there among the cinders,

The ball, the dress, the stroke of midnight—

The real change happens in the quiet moments
When courage takes root in the heart.

Cinderella is the woman rising daily,
Facing trials with dignity intact,
Not waiting for external validation,
But knowing her own worth as fact.

So when you speak of Cinderella,
Remember it's not about the royal wed.

And the powerful path she chose to tread.

The True Magic

Are not what her story's truly for.

Beneath her tattered clothes and weary smile,

A gentle heart, a spirit undefeated,
Carrying grace along her troubled road.

The prince saw not her borrowed finery,

For Cinderella's charm wasn't in her garments,
But in how her inner light could shine.

We all have cinders clinging to our stories,
Moments when we feel unseen, undone,
Yet like her, our true worth isn't measured
By circumstance, but who we've become.

So remember when you hear of Cinderella,
The slipper's fit was never the real test.

Is finding beauty in yourself, expressed.

They trade their wings for heavy chains,

The mountaintops stand bare and cold,
Their paths untrod by human feet.
While in the marketplace below,
The masses chase what's incomplete.

What happened to the searchers bold,
Who once looked up with wondering eyes?
Now bent beneath their worldly loads,
They've lost the urge to theorize.

Yet hidden in forgotten books,
And whispered in the midnight air,
The ancient call still echoes soft:
"Look up! The answers wait you there!"

Perhaps in this distracted age,
When fewer souls dare climb so high,
The truth reveals itself more clear
To those who still can read the sky.

Celestial Seekers

As less on earth seek truth above,
The heavens weep in silent tears.
The cosmos holds its breath and waits
For minds to rise beyond their fears.

We've traded stars for neon lights,
Exchanged deep thought for shallow trends.
The wisdom of a thousand years
Forgotten as attention bends.

Toward fleeting pleasures, quick delights,
The instantaneous and new.
While ancient truths and mysteries
Remain for just the faithful few.

Yet in this age of blinding noise,
Perhaps the seeking grows more pure.
Those few who still gaze upward find
A clearer path, a stronger lure.

For as the masses turn away,
The signal cuts through lessened static.
And those who dare to contemplate
Find wisdom all the more dramatic.

Higher Truths

As less on earth seek truth above,
The sacred paths grow overgrown.
The temples of the mind stand bare,
Their altars cold as lifeless stone.

We chase the tangible and quick,
The measurable, the proven thing.
Forgetting that the greatest truths
Transcend what calculation brings.

The mystic and philosopher
Now labeled dreamers, out of touch,
While pragmatists rule marble halls,
And scorn what they can't grasp or clutch.

But truth cares not for fashion's whim,
Nor bends to match our modern creed.
It waits, patient as mountain rock,
For those who feel the deeper need.

So fewer pilgrims climb the heights,
But those who do find clearer air.
The crowd below may never know
What revelations wait up there.

Skyward Glances

As less on earth seek truth above,
The digital age blinds our sight.
We stare at screens and miss the stars,
That guided seekers through the night.

Once, questions burned in human hearts
Of purpose, meaning, cosmic plan.
Now algorithms plot our course,
And data shapes what makes us man.

The ancient sages would have wept
To see how we've exchanged our gaze—
From contemplation of the gods
To endless scrolling through the days.

Yet still, some souls resist the pull
Of constant earthbound stimuli.
They carve out silence, space, and time
To wonder at the vaulted sky.

Perhaps in scarcity there's strength,
As fewer travelers walk this road.
The truth above shines just as bright,
For those who shed convention's load.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'As less on earth seek truth above'

responses.text:
The Diminished Gaze

As less on earth seek truth above,
The constellations fade from view.
Not from their light diminishing,
But from our gaze turned elsewhere too.

We mine the earth for precious ore,
We scan horizons, chart the seas,
Yet seldom lift our eyes to where
The ancients found their deities.

The modern mind, so practical,
Dismisses what it cannot touch.
Declaring myths what once was faith,
And doubting intuition's clutch.

But truth remains, suspended high,
Beyond the reach of mortal hands.
It does not beg for our belief,
Nor shift to meet our new demands.

Perhaps the few who still look up
Inherit wisdom doubly rare.
A treasure overlooked by most,
Yet freely given to those who dare.

Vertical Journeys

As less on earth seek truth above,
The upward path grows wild with weeds.
The signposts crack, the maps are lost,
While mankind serves more urgent needs.

We've mastered horizontal life—
Expanding, building, spreading wide.
But vertical ascent requires
A different strength we've cast aside.

The mystic's climb, the prophet's quest,
The poet's reach beyond the veil—
All these grow rarer in an age
Where metrics rule and numbers scale.

Yet hidden in forgotten texts,
And whispered in the wind's soft sigh,
Remains the call that some still hear:
To lift your gaze toward distant sky.

For truth above has patience vast,
It waits through ages, calm and still.
And even as the seekers wane,
It holds its light for those who will.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'As less on earth seek truth above'

responses.text:
Skyward Whispers

As less on earth seek truth above,
The cosmos grows more intimate
With those few souls who dare to dream
Beyond what eyes can glimpse or get.

The modern world, a maze of noise,
A labyrinth of gleaming things,
Has dulled our sense of mystery,
Clipped contemplation's soaring wings.

We've traded starlight for the glow
Of screens that promise wisdom quick,
Forgetting that the deepest truths
Reveal themselves to those who stick

With questions that defy the age
Of instant answers, surface deep.
While multitudes chase fleeting trends,
A faithful few their vigils keep.

Perhaps in this—the thinning ranks
Of those who seek beyond the veil—
Lies opportunity most rare:
To hear what whispers soft prevail.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Please spare me your secrets'

responses.text:
Whispered Burdens

Please spare me your secrets,
Those fragile glass birds you hold.
I am not a vault for your darkness,
Nor a priest to grant absolution.

Your truths hang heavy like ripe fruit,
Too sweet, too burdensome to bear.
My shoulders already stoop
With the weight of my own unspoken words.

Please spare me your secrets,
For once shared, they cannot be unheard.
They will nest in my mind at midnight,
When sleep eludes and conscience pricks.

I am but human, fallible and frail,
Not meant to carry two souls' worth of shame.
So keep your whispers locked behind your teeth,
And I will pretend not to see
The shadows dancing in your eyes.

KEEPER OF SILENCE

Please spare me your secrets,
I've chambers enough filled with my own.
Each confession a stone in my pocket,
Dragging me down to depths unknown.

Your whispered truths like smoke
Seep under doorways, stain the walls.
They linger in corners, unwelcome guests
That I never invited at all.

Please spare me your secrets,
For knowledge is a burden, not grace.
I've witnessed how they change you—
How they carve new lines upon your face.

In ignorance, perhaps, lies mercy;
In silence, a kindness of its own.
So keep your revelations close,
Let me walk unburdened, alone.

For secrets are ghosts that haunt the living,
And I've no room for more specters to keep.
Spare me, I beg you, your unspoken truths.
Let me find my way back to sleep.

UNSPOKEN MERCY

Please spare me your secrets,
Those midnight confessions that burn.
I am not the keeper of hidden things,
Nor the ledger where regrets return.

Your untold stories press against my skin
Like rain against a windowpane,
Eager to flood in, to drown the quiet,
To leave no corner of me the same.

Please spare me your secrets,
For once shared, they become mine to bear—
Twin shadows we'll carry between us,
A weight dividing, yet impossible to share.

Some truths are better left in silence,
Like seeds that need not find soil.
Not every thought deserves voice,
Not every fire requires oil.

So keep close your unspoken words.
Let them dissolve like sugar in tea.
In withholding lies its own kindness—
A mercy for both you and me.

THE UNBURDENING

Please spare me your secrets,
I've no room left to store
The whispered confessions of others
Behind my own rusting door.

Each revelation a pebble
Dropped in still waters of trust,
Ripples disturbing reflections
Of who we pretend to be—and must.

Please spare me your secrets,
For I am not your vessel to fill
With the overflow of your conscience,
Your guilt, your shame, your will.

We walk this earth as separate beings,
Connected yet wholly our own.
Some burdens were never meant for sharing,
Some paths must be walked alone.

So keep your unspoken truths close,
Hold them tight against your chest.
I offer you silence, not absolution—
Perhaps in this, we both find rest.

BOUNDARIES

Please spare me your secrets,
Those delicate, dangerous things.
They flutter like moths to flame,
Burning up on transparent wings.

I have built walls for a reason,
Carefully mortared, brick by brick.
Your confidences are battering rams
Against defenses wearing thin.

Please spare me your secrets,
I cannot promise to keep them safe.
They might escape in my dreaming,
Or slip through fingers during day.

There is power in knowing nothing,
In standing outside the circle of truth.
I choose the mercy of ignorance,
The freedom that comes with proof.

So swallow back those revelations,
Let them dissolve on your tongue.
Some words, once spoken, cannot be recalled—
Some bells cannot be unrung.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Please spare me your secrets'

responses.text:
VEILED MERCIES

Please spare me your secrets,
Those heavy pearls you wish to share.
Each one a universe of consequence,
Too vast for my shoulders to bear.

I am but a traveler on my own journey,
Navigating the storms of my making.
Your hidden truths like lightning strikes
Would only leave my small boat breaking.

Please spare me your secrets,
For in knowing lies responsibility—
To act, to judge, to carry forward
What was never mine to see.

There is kindness in withholding,
A mercy in what remains unsaid.
Some gardens are meant to grow untended,
Some thoughts to stay inside your head.

So keep your revelations guarded,
Lock them away from light of day.
I offer not rejection but protection—
For both of us, it's better this way.

THE UNBURDENING

Please spare me your secrets,
I've collected enough of my own—
A treasury of unspoken words
That weigh more than polished stone.

Your confessions hover like shadows,
Eager to find new ground to haunt.
But I am not the vessel you seek,
Nor the absolution that you want.

Please spare me your secrets,
For they change the landscape between us,
Transforming familiar territory
Into something we can no longer discuss.

Some knowledge is better left buried,
Some truths serve no purpose revealed.
The weight of another's conscience
Is too sacred a thing to wield.

So keep your midnight whispers,
Hold them close against your chest.
In silence we find our boundaries—
In boundaries, perhaps, our rest.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Please spare me your secrets'

responses.text:
UNSHARED BURDENS

Please spare me your secrets,
Those jagged shards of truth you hold,
Cut from the stained glass of your past,
Too sharp, too colorful, too bold.

I am already a mosaic of fragments—
Bits of stories, half-truths, and lies
That I've gathered through years of listening
To confessions beneath darkening skies.

Please spare me your secrets,
For each one leaves a permanent mark.
They tattoo themselves on my conscience,
Visible only when the world turns dark.

There is wisdom in selective silence,
A boundary that honors us both.
Some rivers should flow to their own seas,
Some fires burn down to their growth.

So keep your revelations sacred,
Hold them close or set them free.
But release them to the wind or stars—
Anywhere, anywhere but me.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Please spare me your secrets'

responses.text:
Whispered Burdens

Please spare me your secrets,
Those midnight confessions that weigh like stones.
I am not a vault for your hidden transgressions,
Nor a priest to absolve what you've done.

The weight of knowing presses against my temples,
Your whispered truths like chains around my thoughts.
I have my own shadows to wrestle with,
My own ghosts that haunt the corners of my mind.

Please spare me your secrets,
I am already drowning in my own.
The responsibility of silence is a burden
I no longer wish to bear.

There is freedom in the light,
In the unburdening of truth upon the air.
Find another keeper for your darkest tales,
For I am returning yours, unopened, unread.

The Keeper of Silence

Please spare me your secrets,
I have no room left to store
The whispered confessions
That seep beneath my door.

My shoulders already bend
With the weight of untold tales,
Each one a heavy anchor
Dragging me to unknown depths.

I've become a living archive
Of things that shouldn't be known,
A reluctant sanctuary
Where forbidden truths are sown.

The knowledge burns inside me,
A fire I cannot quench.
Each confidence shared
Pulls my soul apart, inch by inch.

So please, I beg of you,
Keep your shadows to yourself.
I am not your confession booth,
Nor your forgotten dusty shelf.

I wish to know the lightness
Of a mind unburdened, free.
Please spare me your secrets—
Let me simply be.

Unspoken Boundaries

Please spare me your secrets,
Those dark and twisted knots.
I have no desire to untangle
The mess of what you've wrought.

Each confession is a pebble
Tossed into my still pond,
Rippling through my conscience,
Disturbing what lies beyond.

I've carried others' burdens
Until my back nearly broke,
Smothered by the weight of words
That should have never been spoke.

Your truths are not my treasures,
Your sins are not my own.
I am not the keeper of your past,
Nor guardian of what you've sown.

So build your walls of silence,
Lock your demons in their cage.
I've learned the cost of knowing
What should stay on your page.

Please spare me your secrets,
I'm reclaiming sacred space.
Some boundaries must remain intact,
Some words leave too deep a trace.

Unwanted Confidences

Please spare me your secrets,
Those fragments of your hidden soul.
I am not the vessel for your pain,
Nor the one to make you whole.

Each revelation is a burden,
A shadow I did not choose to bear.
Your whispered confidences linger
Like smoke that taints the air.

I have listened to your stories,
Held your truths against my chest.
But now I find they haunt me
In moments meant for rest.

There is intimacy in silence,
In the things we choose to hide.
Sometimes boundaries protect us both,
Creating space where peace resides.

So keep your darkest chapters closed,
Your skeletons locked away.
I've learned that some connections
Grow stronger in the light of day.

Please spare me your secrets—
Let's walk a clearer path instead,
Where trust is built on open ground,
Not whispers shared in dread.

The Unburdening

Please spare me your secrets,
I've become too full of others' pain.
A repository of whispered confessions,
A vessel that cannot drain.

Each confidence shared becomes a stone
I carry within my chest.
They rattle and scrape against my ribs,
Robbing me of rest.

I used to think it was a gift—
This trust that made you speak
The words you dare not tell another,
Your voice so soft and weak.

But now I understand the cost
Of being keeper of the keys
To rooms inside your darkened heart
Where no light ever sees.

So build your walls around those thoughts,
Lock them away from sight.
I need to shed the weight of knowing
To find my own clear light.

Please spare me your secrets—
I'm learning how to breathe again,
To exist without the heaviness
Of where you've been and what you've seen.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Please spare me your secrets'

responses.text:
UNBURDEN ME

Please spare me your secrets,
Those jagged pieces of your past.
I am already a mosaic of broken things,
Fragments that cut when I move too fast.

Your confessions hang in the air between us,
Like smoke that stings the eyes and lungs.
I've become the repository of your regrets,
A living archive of things better unsung.

The weight of knowing presses down,
A gravity that bends my spine.
I've carried the atlas of your universe
For far too long a time.

There is beauty in mystery,
In the spaces we choose not to fill.
Some doors are meant to stay closed,
Some truths designed to kill.

So keep your whispers to yourself,
Lock away what haunts your sleep.
I am reclaiming my own silence now,
No more of your ghosts to keep.

SANCTUARY OF SILENCE

Please spare me your secrets,
I've no more room within these walls.
My heart, once an eager listener,
Now echoes with too many calls.

Each confession you've placed in my hands
Is a bird I cannot set free.
They flutter against my ribcage,
Demanding I let them be.

I've been the keeper of your darkness,
The guardian of your shame.
But these secrets have become heavy chains,
And I'm no longer the same.

The things you've whispered in twilight
Have stolen my peaceful nights.
I find myself drowning in knowledge
That dims my own inner light.

So please, find another vessel
To pour your hidden truths inside.
I'm sealing the cracks in my fortress,
Reclaiming the peace that's mine.

Please spare me your secrets—
I'm learning to breathe again.
In the sacred space of silence,
Where your words can't enter in.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Please spare me your secrets'

responses.text:
THE UNBURDENED LISTENER

Please spare me your secrets,
Those midnight whispers that stain the soul.
I am not a cathedral for your confessions,
Nor a well where your sins should roll.

Each revelation you've entrusted
Etches itself on my mind's eye,
A gallery of shadows not my own,
Obscuring my own starlit sky.

There was a time I wore your trust
Like medals pinned upon my chest,
But now they weigh like anchors
Dragging me from peaceful rest.

Some boundaries are sacred temples,
Some silences a blessed balm.
The space between what's known and hidden
Is where we both might find our calm.

So hold your stories close and dear,
Or release them to the wind instead.
I'm returning your keys to locked rooms
To walk unburdened paths ahead.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Please spare me your secrets'

responses.text:
Whispers in the Dark

Please spare me your secrets,
those shadows you harbor deep within.
I am but a vessel, already brimming
with my own unspoken truths.

Your confessions hover like moths
around a flame that's barely lit.
My shoulders, though willing,
bend under invisible weight.

There is beauty in mystery,
in the spaces between knowing.
Sometimes silence speaks louder
than midnight revelations.

Keep your burdens wrapped
in the tissue paper of discretion.
Not every thought needs air,
not every wound needs witness.

Please spare me your secrets.
Let them dissolve like morning fog,
or carry them until they transform
into something you no longer fear to name.

Burden of Knowing

Please spare me your secrets,
I've no room left to keep them safe.
Each whispered confession
Carves another chamber in my chest.

The weight of what I know about you
Bends my spine like willow branches.
Your truths stick to my ribs,
Pulsing with each anxious heartbeat.

I've become a cathedral of confidences,
Stained glass windows colored with
All the words you couldn't say aloud.
My echoing halls filled with your ghosts.

Don't you see how they haunt me?
These fragments of your hidden self
That I never asked to shelter.

Please spare me your secrets.
I am already drowning in my own,
Gasping for air in this ocean
Of things we pretend not to know.

Boundaries

Please spare me your secrets,
Those midnight confessions that spill
Like ink across pristine pages.
I have built walls for a reason,
Carefully mortared with distance.

Your truths are beautiful birds
With razor-sharp beaks and talons.
Once released, they cannot be recaged,
And I bear the scars of knowledge
That was never mine to carry.

There is intimacy in silence,
Respect in the spaces we leave sacred.
Not everything dark needs light,
Not every wound needs witness.

Keep those delicate treasures
Locked in the vault of your chest.
I offer instead a different communion:
The gentle grace of unknowing,
The freedom of separate journeys,
Parallel lines that need not intersect
To still travel beneath the same sky.

The Keeper of Silences

Please spare me your secrets,
For I am not the keeper you seek.
Each confession you place at my feet
Is another stone I must carry uphill.

I've collected too many already—
A museum of others' hidden shames,
Fragile exhibits I dare not disturb
For fear they might shatter us both.

Your unspoken words hover between us,
Eager to bridge the gap of understanding.
But some bridges, once crossed,
Cannot bear the weight of return.

I offer instead a different kindness:
The mercy of unspoken thoughts,
The grace of questions unasked,
The gentle art of looking away.

Please spare me your secrets.
Let them rest in the soil of your heart
Where they might decompose quietly
And nourish only the growth you choose.

Unspoken

Please spare me your secrets,
those midnight whispers that burn
like acid on unprepared skin.
I am not your confessional booth,
nor your journal's blank page.

Each revelation you place in my hands
becomes a contract I never signed.
Knowledge is a currency
I cannot return once spent,
a burden with compound interest.

There is power in the unsaid,
beauty in the mystery of faces
that show only what they choose.
We are all entitled to our depths,
our hidden caverns of self.

Let us instead share the surface waters,
the gentle ripples of everyday truths.
There is intimacy enough in weather,
in the passing of seasons,
in the simple acknowledgment
that we are both still breathing.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Please spare me your secrets'

responses.text:
Guardians of Silence

Please spare me your secrets,
Those heavy stones you've carried too long.
I am but a paper boat on troubled waters,
Not built to bear the weight of hidden wrongs.

Your untold stories hover in the spaces
Between our careful words and measured smiles.
I feel them pressing at the edges,
Shadows stretching across these fragile miles.

Some truths are better left as whispers
Between your soul and midnight's gentle ear.
Not every darkness needs illumination,
Not every wound needs witness to heal clear.

I offer you instead a kinder mercy:
The freedom of your burdens kept your own,
The dignity of private transformation,
The peace of knowing you're not judged unknown.

Please spare me your secrets.
Let them dissolve or flourish as they may.
I'll walk beside you through the silence,
And love the self you choose to show today.

Unshared Burdens

Please spare me your secrets,
those midnight confessions
that slip between teeth like smoke.
I have no room left in my ribcage
for truths that aren't mine to hold.

Each revelation is a stone
dropped into still water—
the ripples change everything,
redraw the shoreline of what we were
before the knowing.

There are some words
that once spoken
cannot be unheard,
some doors that once opened
lead only forward, never back.

I am already heavy
with my own unspoken things,
carrying them carefully
like eggs in a basket,
terrified of the breaking.

Please spare me your secrets.
Let us instead share the light:
the weather, the passing clouds,
the gentle communion of silence
between two souls who understand
that not everything needs saying.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Please spare me your secrets'

responses.text:

Please spare me your secrets,
those midnight revelations that stain like wine.

threads woven so tight I can scarcely breathe.

Each confession you contemplate
hovers between us like a hummingbird,
beautiful but demanding sustenance
I no longer have strength to provide.

There is an intimacy in boundaries,
a tenderness in the choice to withhold.
Sometimes the greatest gift we give
is the burden we choose not to share.

Let your mysteries remain constellations
I admire from a distance,
rather than maps I must memorize
and territories I must defend.

Please spare me your secrets.

where sunlight defines our shadows
and what remains hidden nourishes only you.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Please spare me your secrets'

responses.text:
# Whispers Unheard

Please spare me your secrets,
Those midnight confessions you long to release.
I am but a vessel already brimming with shadows,
Carrying echoes of truths not mine to keep.

Your words are beautiful burdens,
Heavy with histories I cannot shoulder.
My ears are not vaults for your hidden sorrows,
Nor sanctuaries for the ghosts you've gathered.

Please spare me your secrets,
For once known, they cannot be unknown.
They will dance between us like specters,
Altering the light in which we've grown.

Save your revelations for someone stronger,
Or better yet, set them free to the wind.
I am just a traveler on this road beside you,
Not the keeper of the stories you've penned.

# The Weight of Knowing

Please spare me your secrets,
Those whispered confessions in twilight hours.
I've collected too many already,
A garden of others' hidden flowers.

Each revelation a stone in my pocket,
Dragging me deeper into waters unknown.
Your truths would be beautiful, I'm certain,
But my soul has too many seeds already sown.

The burden of knowing weighs heavy,
Like atlas with the world upon his back.
Your secrets deserve sacred keeping,
But my shoulders have begun to crack.

So please, hold close your unspoken words,
Cherish them or release them to the sky.
I am but human with limited spaces,
For the intimate whispers others rely.

Please spare me your secrets,
Not for lack of caring or trust.
But because some vessels are already filled
With mysteries turning to dust.

# Unspoken Boundaries

Please spare me your secrets,
Those fragments of self you hide away.
I am not the confessor you seek,
Nor the absolution of yesterday.

Your truths are galaxies untold,
Stars burning bright in midnight skies.
But I am just a passerby,
Ill-equipped for such magnificent size.

Each confession builds a bridge
Connecting souls across the void.
But some bridges bear too much weight,
Collapsing what should be enjoyed.

I honor your need to speak,
To breathe life into silent pain.
But boundaries protect us both,
Like shelter from the pouring rain.

Please spare me your secrets,
Not because they lack worth or grace,
But because some gardens grow better
When given their own sacred space.

# The Keeper's Decline

Please spare me your secrets,
I've become a repository of shadows,
A library of whispered confessions
That were never mine to catalog.

Each revelation you entrust
Becomes a thread in this tapestry of burden.
I wear your unspoken truths like a cloak,
Heavy with the weight of your hidden garden.

Do you not see how they change me?
These secrets that slip between my ribs,
Nestling close to my reluctant heart,
Rewriting the person I thought I was.

I've forgotten which darkness is mine,
Which fears sprouted from my own soil.
Your secrets have become my memories,
A borrowed past I cannot return.

So please, keep your beautiful mysteries.
Lock them away or set them free.
I am not the vault you believe me to be,
Just a person trying to remember me.

# Sacred Silence

Please spare me your secrets,
Those delicate paper birds of truth
Folded with trembling fingers
And set free in the night.

I've learned that knowing is a burden,
A sweet poison that transforms the listener.
Once your words enter my ears,
They cannot be unheard or forgotten.

Some revelations are beautiful daggers,
Glittering with honesty and trust.
But even the most exquisite blade
Leaves a wound where it touched.

I cherish our unburdened moments,
The lightness of unknowing between us.
That sacred space where we can simply be,
Without the gravity of confessions.

So please spare me your secrets,
Not from lack of love or care.
But because sometimes silence
Is the most honest prayer.

# Keepers of Dust

Please spare me your secrets,
For I am already drowning in revelations not my own.
Each whispered confession becomes a ghost,
Haunting the corridors of my mind when I'm alone.

Your truths may glitter like precious stones,
Tempting in their forbidden allure.
But I've learned that knowledge is not always power—
Sometimes it's a labyrinth with no cure.

The universe of your unspoken thoughts
Deserves a guardian stronger than I,
One who can hold your darkness without flinching,
Without letting their own light slowly die.

I want to know you by what you freely give,
The laughter shared under open skies,
Not by the weight of words that bind us
To a contract neither signed but both must abide.

So please spare me your secrets;
Let them dissolve like morning mist,
Or find them homes in journals and prayers
Where they can exist without making prisoners of us.

# The Archivist's Plea

Please spare me your secrets,
I've become an unwilling library of others' pain,
Shelves buckling under whispered confessions,
Ink-stained memories that were never mine to maintain.

Each revelation arrives like a bird with broken wings,
Seeking shelter in the hollow of my chest.
I nurse them carefully, these fragile things,
But my sanctuary has no room for more guests.

Do you understand what happens to a person
Who carries too many stories not their own?
We become translucent, ghosts of ourselves,
Echoing chambers for seeds others have sown.

I cherish our connection built on present moments,
The simple joy of walking the same road.
But those midnight truths you're desperate to release
Will only increase my already impossible load.

So please spare me your secrets,
Find another way to set them free.
Write them to ashes, sing them to the wind,
Or simply let them be.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'ADIEU, O soldier!'

responses.text:
ADIEU, O SOLDIER!

Farewell, brave heart, who marched through fire and lead,
Your boots now silent on the dusty road.
The battlefield's cry no longer fills your head,
As you depart from war's heavy load.

The flag you carried, tattered yet still proud,
Will wave in memory of your steadfast might.
Your courage spoke not whispered, but aloud,
Through darkest day and longest, coldest night.

What stories sleep beneath your medals bright?
What fears conquered beneath your stoic face?
How many dawns did you await first light,
Far from the comfort of a loved one's embrace?

Adieu, O soldier! May your spirit find
The peace you fought for, leaving pain behind.

ADIEU, O SOLDIER!

Steel-eyed guardian of liberty's flame,
Your uniform now folded, crisp and clean.
The world that called you forth is not the same
As that to which you return, changed, unseen.

The thunder of the guns has ceased its roar,
Yet echoes still within your silent dreams.
You carried burdens that no soul should bear,
Across vast oceans, mountains, desert streams.

Adieu, O soldier! Time to lay to rest
The vigilant watch you kept through endless nights.
Return now to the home that loves you best,
Exchange your battles for more gentle fights.

Your country stands because you dared to fall,
Your sacrifice remembered by us all.

ADIEU, O SOLDIER!

The bugle sounds its melancholy note,
As shadows lengthen on the field of rest.
Your valor and your oath, they both denote
A life that put our freedom to the test.

Adieu, O soldier! Time has claimed your youth,
The years of service etched upon your face.
Your quiet strength revealed the simple truth:
That honor lives in sacrifice and grace.

How many sunsets watched from foreign shores?
How many letters penned by candlelight?
How many prayers amid the battle's roars?
How many comrades lost from mortal sight?

The nation bows its head in solemn praise,
For one who walked through war's most bitter days.

ADIEU, O SOLDIER!

Not with a bang but with a whispered sigh,
You shed the armor that has been your skin.
The stars look different now against the sky,
As civilian life can finally begin.

Adieu, O soldier! Child of storm and strife,
Who traded youth for duty's heavy crown.
Now navigate the gentler maps of life,
Where dangers lurk in smiles, not battle's frown.

The medals that adorn your dress blues tell
A fraction of the story in your eyes.
Some memories are harder to dispel
Than morning fog beneath the summer skies.

May peace become your faithful new command,
As you walk softly through your native land.

ADIEU, O SOLDIER!

The parade ground empties as the day grows old,
Your silhouette against the setting sun.
So many stories left forever untold,
As chapters close on battles lost and won.

The flag you pledged your sacred honor to
Still waves above the land you held so dear.
Though time marches on with rhythms new,
Your legacy remains both sharp and clear.

Adieu, O soldier! Rest your weary hands,
The watch is passed to those who follow now.
Across divided seas and distant lands,
Your sacrifice taught others why and how.

In peaceful fields where poppies gently sway,
We'll remember what you gave away.
